entry.et: Middle English plesen, from Anglo-French plaisir, pleisir, pleire, from Latin placēre; akin to Latin placare to placate and perhaps to Greek plak-, plax flat surface fluke

def.dt: :to afford or give pleasure or satisfaction
:to have the kindness will you please to enter the carriage Charles Dickens
:to be the will or pleasure of may it please Your Majesty

dt.un: used as a function word to express politeness or emphasis in a request please come in
used as a function word to express polite affirmation like some tea? Please
used as a function word to express scornful disagreement, disapproval, or disbelief you believe that? Oh, please
